conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on the suitcase and use the given information to find the angle θ and the coefficient of friction μ.
The image shows a suitcase which can be either pushed or pulled on the ground.
The total mass of the suitcase is 15 kg, and a passenger pulls the suitcase with an oblique upward pull to do uniform movement on the horizontal ground.

The minimum value of the pull is 90 N, the angle between the pull and the horizontal direction is θ, the magnitude of gravitational acceleration is g = 10 m/s², sin 37° = 0.6, and the force of gravity is 10 m/s².
The resistance of the suitcase to the ground is proportional to the supporting force of the ground, the ratio is μ.
The suitcase has wheels and a handle for pulling.

premise: Gravitational Force (Fg) acts downward, Fg = mg = 15 kg × 10 m/s² = 150 N.
conclusion: The gravitational force acting on the suitcase is 150 N.

premise: Normal Force (N) acts upward, perpendicular to the ground.
conclusion: The normal force acts upward, balancing the gravitational force and the vertical component of the applied force.

premise: Applied Force (F) is 90 N at an angle θ above the horizontal.
conclusion: The applied force is 90 N at an angle θ.

premise: Frictional Force (f) acts opposite to the direction of motion, f = μN.
conclusion: The frictional force is proportional to the normal force with a coefficient μ.

premise: Resolve the Applied Force: Horizontal component: F cos θ, Vertical component: F sin θ.
conclusion: The applied force has a horizontal component of F cos θ and a vertical component of F sin θ.

premise: Equilibrium Conditions: Horizontal Direction: F cos θ = f = μN.
conclusion: The horizontal component of the applied force balances the frictional force.

premise: Vertical Direction: N + F sin θ = mg.
conclusion: The vertical component of the applied force and the normal force balance the gravitational force.

premise: Substitute N from the Vertical Direction into the Horizontal Direction: N = mg - F sin θ.
conclusion: The normal force is N = mg - F sin θ.

premise: Substitute N into the horizontal direction equation: F cos θ = μ (mg - F sin θ).
conclusion: The equation becomes F cos θ = μ (mg - F sin θ).
